data.source: Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) individual-level survey; validated with Flash Eurobarometer Survey on Entrepreneurship (FESE)
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual respondents (aggregated to country–age–year cells for some analyses)
data.access_details: GEM data available upon application to the Global Entrepreneurship Research Association; FESE publicly available via the European Commission
data.notes: Demographic statistics merged from U.S. Census Bureau International Data Base; extensive country-level controls added (GDP, education, agriculture share, startup costs, property rights, compulsory military service)

method.description: The authors link cross-country GEM survey data on early-stage business ownership to demographic statistics and estimate reduced-form regressions that relate entrepreneurship rates to measures of population age structure.
steps: Assemble GEM micro-data for 82 countries (2001–2010) and construct entrepreneurship indicators (e.g., managing and owning a wage-paying business ≤42 months old).
Merge country-year demographic variables (median age, cohort shrinkage parameter r, share younger than target age s_a) from U.S. Census Bureau International Data Base.
Create country-year and country-age-year analytic datasets weighted by cell population counts.

Add economic and institutional controls: GDP per capita & growth (Penn World Table), education attainment, agriculture share, startup costs (World Bank), property-rights index, compulsory military service length.
Estimate OLS regressions of entrepreneurship rate on demographic variables with and without country fixed effects, clustering errors at country level.
Test theoretical propositions (rank effect, youth effect, inverted-U with age) and conduct robustness checks using alternative entrepreneurship definitions, OECD subsample, and FESE data.
method.models: Weighted ordinary least squares (OLS) regressions at country-year and country-age-year levels; specifications include linear and quadratic age terms and interactions with demographic parameters.
method.outcome_variable: Entrepreneurship rate (e.g., share of individuals managing/owning a new business ≤42 months old that pays wages)
method.independent_variables: Median age, demographic shrinkage parameter r, share younger population s_a, individual age, age squared, compulsory military service, interaction terms
method.control_variables: GDP per capita, GDP growth rate, education level, share of agriculture in GDP, startup costs, property rights index, country fixed effects

results.summary: Across 82 countries, older population structures are associated with markedly lower entrepreneurship. A one-standard-deviation decrease in median age raises the new-business formation rate by about 2.5 percentage points—roughly 40 % of the mean rate. The negative effect of aging holds within every age group, is strongest for middle-aged cohorts, and is robust to alternative definitions, subsamples, and datasets (FESE).

numerical_results.unit: percentage points change for 1 SD lower median age
